commit_message:
libvirt: fix detach volume race condition

When a volume is detached, the according share file is
detached if no longer used. This can cause issues if at the same
time, a different volume stored on the same share is being
attached as the according disk image will not be available.
This patch fixes the issue by tracking share usage.

Change-Id: I7b7ad794b1e15dcd63344e01a520d6c595a73d70
Closes-Bug: #1421550
Closes-Bug: #1461081
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/10/290510/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import collections def __init__(self, connection): self.export_usage = collections.defaultdict(list) def test_update_export_usage_connected(self): self.driver.update_export_usage(mock.sentinel.export, mock.sentinel.resurce) self.assertEqual([mock.sentinel.resurce], self.driver.export_usage[mock.sentinel.export]) def test_update_export_usage_disconnected(self): self.driver.export_usage[mock.sentinel.export] = [ mock.sentinel.resurce] self.driver.update_export_usage(mock.sentinel.export, mock.sentinel.resurce, connected=False) self.assertNotIn([mock.sentinel.export], self.driver.export_usage)

commit_message:
Use min attribute from oslo_config

"min=0" is now introduced in oslo_config, so no
need to check for negative integer in code for
"block_device_allocate_retries".

DocImpact: nova-compute service will fail to
start if negative value is specified for
"block_device_allocate_retries" parameter.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: Ida7b2e8322175ff566eef2b23130a9293d0d9f0b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/10/362110/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # (1) the configured value is 0, one attempt should be made # (2) the configured value is > 0, then the total number attempts
deleted_lines: if retries < 0: LOG.warning(_LW("Treating negative config value (%(retries)s) for " "'block_device_retries' as 0."), {'retries': retries}) # (1) treat negative config value as 0 # (2) the configured value is 0, one attempt should be made # (3) the configured value is > 0, then the total number attempts

commit_message:
Increase the possible size of the flavor extra_spec value

The maximum size of the flavor extra_spec value is 255 character [1],
but this is not always enough. There are cases where it is too small
so we need to increase (see: bug report)

[1] : https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/9c89e07/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api_models.py#L206

Change-Id: I79564032fe160421455a57fc2628b2f05d51b905
Closes-Bug: 1630463

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-20 14:40:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/32ae001c64e514c204575edb378afcb03a300ec2', 'message': 'Evacuation of VM fails to plug on Destination

corresponding host is shut down immediately before VIF active state in

By examining compute log on source Host, you can determine if
InstanceInfoCache has been updated to active=True or not.

When such a VM is evacuated to destination host, since vif state is not active
it goes into stale state and any attempt to plug goes nowhere. This is due to
communication is sent to wrong host (source instead of destination).

in compute manager. It sets active state of all VIFs in the VM to true. This
is how it will be if  VIF state becomes active on source host before it goes
down.

All corresponding unit tests in test_compute and test_compute_mgr have been
updated.

commit_message:
Evacuation of VM fails to plug on Destination

This evacuation problem can be reproduced with deployment of VM and
corresponding host is shut down immediately before VIF active state in
InstanceInfoCache is updated to True from False for corresponding VM.
By examining compute log on source Host, you can determine if
InstanceInfoCache has been updated to active=True or not.

When such a VM is evacuated to destination host, since vif state is not
active it goes into stale state and any attempt to plug goes nowhere.
This is due to communication is sent to wrong host (source instead of
destination).

This patchset fixes this problem by adding logic to rebuild_instance
method in compute manager. It sets active state of all VIFs in the VM
to true. This is how it will be if VIF state becomes active on source
host before it goes down.

All corresponding unit tests in test_compute and test_compute_mgr have
been updated.

Change-Id: Iba46e3eeeff622e700ad835c936c293fa057b55d
Closes-Bug: 1535918

added_lines: # NOTE(svenkat): During evacuate, if any of the vif is not # active, it causes vif-plugged event not to be processed. deleted_lines: from oslo_concurrency import processutilsfrom nova.i18n import _LE, _LWdef mount_share(mount_path, export_path, export_type, options=None): """Mount a remote export to mount_path. :param mount_path: place where the remote export will be mounted :param export_path: path of the export to be mounted :export_type: remote export type (e.g. cifs, nfs, etc.) :options: A list containing mount options """ utils.execute('mkdir', '-p', mount_path) mount_cmd = ['mount', '-t', export_type] if options is not None: mount_cmd.extend(options) mount_cmd.extend([export_path, mount_path]) try: utils.execute(*mount_cmd, run_as_root=True) except processutils.ProcessExecutionError as exc: if 'Device or resource busy' in six.text_type(exc): LOG.warning(_LW("%s is already mounted"), export_path) else: raise def unmount_share(mount_path, export_path): """Unmount a remote share. :param mount_path: remote export mount point :param export_path: path of the remote export to be unmounted """ try: utils.execute('umount', mount_path, run_as_root=True, attempts=3, delay_on_retry=True) except processutils.ProcessExecutionError as exc: if 'target is busy' in six.text_type(exc): LOG.debug("The share %s is still in use.", export_path) else: LOG.exception(_LE("Couldn't unmount the share %s"), export_path)

libvirt: Fix races with glusterfs volume mount/umount

Change-Id: Id9c9da4fd5ce57367d60eab9618ddbddfe9d56c4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/61/383861/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.mount_manager.mount(self, connection_info) self.mount_manager.umount(self, connection_info) def mount_cmd(self, connection_info): options = connection_info['data'].get('options') mount_cmd = ['mount', '-t', 'glusterfs'] if options is not None: mount_cmd.extend(options.split(' '))
deleted_lines: from oslo_concurrency import processutilsimport sixfrom nova.i18n import _LE, _LW from nova import utils from nova.virt.libvirt import utils as libvirt_utils self._ensure_mounted(connection_info) mount_path = self._get_mount_path(connection_info) try: utils.execute('umount', mount_path, run_as_root=True) except processutils.ProcessExecutionError as exc: export = connection_info['data']['export'] if 'target is busy' in six.text_type(exc): LOG.debug("The GlusterFS share %s is still in use.", export) else: LOG.exception(_LE("Couldn't unmount the GlusterFS share %s"), export) def _ensure_mounted(self, connection_info): """@type connection_info: dict """ glusterfs_export = connection_info['data']['export'] mount_path = self._get_mount_path(connection_info) if not libvirt_utils.is_mounted(mount_path, glusterfs_export): options = connection_info['data'].get('options') self._mount_glusterfs(mount_path, glusterfs_export, options, ensure=True) return mount_path def _mount_glusterfs(self, mount_path, glusterfs_share, options=None, ensure=False): """Mount glusterfs export to mount path.""" utils.execute('mkdir', '-p', mount_path) gluster_cmd = ['mount', '-t', 'glusterfs'] if options is not None: gluster_cmd.extend(options.split(' ')) gluster_cmd.extend([glusterfs_share, mount_path]) try: utils.execute(*gluster_cmd, run_as_root=True) except processutils.ProcessExecutionError as exc: if ensure and 'already mounted' in six.text_type(exc): LOG.warning(_LW("%s is already mounted"), glusterfs_share) else: raise

commit_message:
[POC][placement] Amend r-p/{uuid}/traits PUT to support os-traits

This patch amends /resource_providers/{uuid}/traits PUT to support
os-traits library. If the specified *custom* traits don't exist in the
placement database, it will return HTTP 400. And a 404 could happen if
the resource provider uuid is invalid.

Partial implement blueprint resource-provider-tags

Change-Id: I6ea5d247f5d279af50fd43ca7bab631321a81b92
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/01/378601/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: standard_traits, other_traits = ot.check_traits(traits) trait_objs = objects.TraitList.get_all(context, filters={'traits': traits}) recorded_traits = set(_serialize_traits(trait_objs)['traits']) invalid_traits = other_traits - recorded_traits if invalid_traits: raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest( _("Invalid Traits in the request: %s") % invalid_traits, json_formatter=util.json_error_formatter) objects.TraitList.add_all(context, standard_traits)
deleted_lines: trait_objs = objects.TraitList.get_all(context, filters={'traits': traits}) if len(trait_objs) != len(traits): # TODO(alex_xu): better error info. raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest( _("Invalid Traits in the request"), json_formatter=util.json_error_formatter)

commit_message:
[POC][placement] Amend traits modification api to support os-traits

This patch amends PUT '/traits' to allow admin users to modify only the
user-defined traits. Any attempts to put a standard trait will result in
HTTP 409.

This patch also amends DELETE '/traits' to allow admin users to delete
only the user-defined traits.

Partial implement blueprint resource-provider-tags

Change-Id: I1523174d4290bd8aef84d8c9447cd9199cbe128c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/90/377690/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Make api-paste.ini part of python module

In part of the effort to make api-paste.ini code (rather than config)
lets move the ini file in to our python module. Also deprecate the
api_paste_config config option since it is no longer needed.

Change-Id: I83a10f9ccfcab2eb82c6844eddec5b56b49f278c

post live migration methods. However, we need to keep block_migration
argument in RPC for backward compatibility, but we can pass
migrate_data.block_migration instead of just block_migration.

Change-Id: Iba9f9963b94bd51de2fddf42532a3dd8e8ecf94f

commit_message:
Remove block_migration from LM post operations

Right now information about migration type is stored in migrate_data
object, so we can remove block_migration argument from almost all
post live migration methods. However, we need to keep block_migration
argument in RPC for backward compatibility, but we can pass
migrate_data.block_migration instead of just block_migration.

Change-Id: Iba9f9963b94bd51de2fddf42532a3dd8e8ecf94f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/15/295315/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _post_live_migration(self, ctxt, instance, dest, migrate_data=None): # NOTE(pkoniszewski): Unfortunately block_migration might not be # a part of migrate_data object. Also we need this for backward # compatibility of RPC API. block_migration = False if migrate_data and 'block_migration' in migrate_data: block_migration = migrate_data.block_migration context, instance, network_info, block_device_info)
deleted_lines: def _post_live_migration(self, ctxt, instance, dest, block_migration=False, migrate_data=None): :param block_migration: if true, prepare for block migration context, instance, network_info, block_migration, block_device_info)

commit_message:
Add the libvirt.ephemeral_image_format config option

This allows new ephemeral images to be optionally created
with type qcow2 rather than raw.

Wikimedia Labs has been running with this change hacked
into libvirt for many years.  It appears that there
is some interest from other users, as per
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-operators/2015-October/008520.html

Change-Id: Ie9e97dccb96c9ff6b82df2dc698db23056a9cc79
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/61/301861/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.StrOpt('ephemeral_format', default='default', choices=('raw', 'qcow2', 'default'), help='File type for ephemeral images. Type qcow2 may be useful' ' in setups that use a small number of base images and rely on' ' disk space overprovisioning.'),

Stop using mox from unit/fake_network.py

nova/tests/unit/fake_network.py and related files.

Partially-Implements: blueprint remove-mox-ocata

commit_message:
Update references for split up hardware module

The hardware module has been split. Let's update the references,
renaming any functions to remove duplication of module names.

Change-Id: Iaffad530dc1da8357a2b3f618cac7dcac0233b1b

commit_message:
Remove block_migration argument from live migration operations

Because block_migration is not used during the live migration operations,
we can safely mark it as deprecated.

Change-Id: I9276a6c00e7b4ec9d287fe94473d62122eb69141

commit_message:
Add support for detaching interfaces in ironic

This change implements support for detaching specified interface of
baremetal node.
For proper detach, interface should be unplugged by ironic.
Also uplug required for deleting port from neutron.

Partial-bug: 1609097
Change-Id: I1cd6cac590392c6f813fd5679f9e0f254b735ee5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/10/347410/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # not needed if no vif are defined for vif in network_info: for pif in ports: if vif['address'] == pif.address and 'vif_port_id' in pif.extra: # we can not attach a dict directly patch = [{'op': 'remove', 'path': '/extra/vif_port_id'}] try: self.ironicclient.call("port.update", pif.uuid, patch) except ironic.exc.BadRequest: pass def detach_interface(self, instance, vif): self.unplug_vifs(instance, [vif])
deleted_lines: # not needed if no vif are defined for pif in ports: if 'vif_port_id' in pif.extra: # we can not attach a dict directly patch = [{'op': 'remove', 'path': '/extra/vif_port_id'}] try: self.ironicclient.call("port.update", pif.uuid, patch) except ironic.exc.BadRequest: pass

commit_message:
WIP: api: discoverable policy

Adds validation schemas for several API actions.

Adds os-endpoints API Controller. Returns API endpoints
and their schema validations based on the request's
API microversion.

Implements: blueprint discoverable-api-endpoints

Change-Id: I9afb58787036b4fbdfd1208722c273c8bd95eb44

commit_message:
Mutable compute options: reserves, ratios

Make these options mutable:

    DEFAULT/reserved_host_disk_mb
    DEFAULT/reserved_host_memory_mb
    DEFAULT/cpu_allocation_ratio
    DEFAULT/ram_allocation_ratio
    DEFAULT/disk_allocation_ratio

The reservations present no difficulty. The ratios are copied about a
bit, I am not concerned about the HostState objects as these are
transient. I think the usages by cells and NUMATopologyLimits are also
OK.

bp mutable-config-ocata

Change-Id: I1011a28bfc0d3021acd8fc889c0d74f5fe2a8068
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/61/349561/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: self.ram_allocation_ratio = CONF.ram_allocation_ratio self.cpu_allocation_ratio = CONF.cpu_allocation_ratio self.disk_allocation_ratio = CONF.disk_allocation_ratio self.compute_node.ram_allocation_ratio = self.ram_allocation_ratio self.compute_node.cpu_allocation_ratio = self.cpu_allocation_ratio self.compute_node.disk_allocation_ratio = self.disk_allocation_ratio

subject: hardware: Split into modules
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-08 15:41:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/22ea726c1b2069d4e1cc50da49421c84133eee8d', 'message': "virt: Split out 'numa' and 'compat' modules

The 'hardware' file is currently a bit of catch-all:

* NUMA CPU and hugepage calculation utilities
* General CPU calculation utilities
* Serial port utilities
* Wrappers to handle hosts that don't pass objects over RPC
* Some other stuff...

Rather than mixing all this functionality together, the code should be
modularized. As such, split this file and dependendent tests into

commit_message:
hardware: Split into modules

The 'hardware' file is currently a bit of catch-all:

* NUMA CPU and hugepage calculation utilities
* General CPU calculation utilities
* Serial port utilities
* Wrappers to handle hosts that don't pass objects over RPC
* Some other stuff...

Rather than mixing all this functionality together, the code should be
modularized. As such, split this file and dependendent tests into
separate modules. Imports are included in __init__ to prevent the
need to big-bang covert all the callers in the same change.

Change-Id: I617e1168e115dda92658b107ee54795ab7d14e0b

added_lines: # Copyright 2014, 2016 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import uuid import mock from oslo_serialization import jsonutils import six from nova import context from nova import objects from nova.objects import base as base_obj from nova import test from nova.tests import uuidsentinel as uuids from nova.virt import compat class HelperMethodsTestCase(test.NoDBTestCase): def setUp(self): super(HelperMethodsTestCase, self).setUp() self.hosttopo = objects.NUMATopology(cells=[ objects.NUMACell(id=0, cpuset=set([0, 1]), memory=512, memory_usage=0, cpu_usage=0, mempages=[], siblings=[], pinned_cpus=set([])), objects.NUMACell(id=1, cpuset=set([2, 3]), memory=512, memory_usage=0, cpu_usage=0, mempages=[], siblings=[], pinned_cpus=set([])), ]) self.instancetopo = objects.InstanceNUMATopology( instance_uuid=uuids.instance, cells=[ objects.InstanceNUMACell( id=0, cpuset=set([0, 1]), memory=256, pagesize=2048, cpu_pinning={0: 0, 1: 1}), objects.InstanceNUMACell( id=1, cpuset=set([2]), memory=256, pagesize=2048, cpu_pinning={2: 3}), ]) self.context = context.RequestContext('fake-user', 'fake-project') def _check_usage(self, host_usage): self.assertEqual(2, host_usage.cells[0].cpu_usage) self.assertEqual(256, host_usage.cells[0].memory_usage) self.assertEqual(1, host_usage.cells[1].cpu_usage) self.assertEqual(256, host_usage.cells[1].memory_usage) def test_dicts_json(self): host = {'numa_topology': self.hosttopo._to_json()} instance = {'numa_topology': self.instancetopo._to_json()} res = compat.get_host_numa_usage_from_instance(host, instance) self.assertIsInstance(res, six.string_types) self._check_usage(objects.NUMATopology.obj_from_db_obj(res)) def test_dicts_instance_json(self): host = {'numa_topology': self.hosttopo} instance = {'numa_topology': self.instancetopo._to_json()} res = compat.get_host_numa_usage_from_instance(host, instance) self.assertIsInstance(res, objects.NUMATopology) self._check_usage(res) def test_dicts_instance_json_old(self): host = {'numa_topology': self.hosttopo} instance = {'numa_topology': jsonutils.dumps(self.instancetopo._to_dict())} res = compat.get_host_numa_usage_from_instance(host, instance) self.assertIsInstance(res, objects.NUMATopology) self._check_usage(res) def test_dicts_host_json(self): host = {'numa_topology': self.hosttopo._to_json()} instance = {'numa_topology': self.instancetopo} res = compat.get_host_numa_usage_from_instance(host, instance) self.assertIsInstance(res, six.string_types) self._check_usage(objects.NUMATopology.obj_from_db_obj(res)) def test_dicts_host_json_old(self): host = {'numa_topology': jsonutils.dumps( self.hosttopo._to_dict())} instance = {'numa_topology': self.instancetopo} res = compat.get_host_numa_usage_from_instance(host, instance) self.assertIsInstance(res, six.string_types) self._check_usage(objects.NUMATopology.obj_from_db_obj(res)) def test_object_host_instance_json(self): host = objects.ComputeNode(numa_topology=self.hosttopo._to_json()) instance = {'numa_topology': self.instancetopo._to_json()} res = compat.get_host_numa_usage_from_instance(host, instance) self.assertIsInstance(res, six.string_types) self._check_usage(objects.NUMATopology.obj_from_db_obj(res)) def test_object_host_instance(self): host = objects.ComputeNode(numa_topology=self.hosttopo._to_json()) instance = {'numa_topology': self.instancetopo} res = compat.get_host_numa_usage_from_instance(host, instance) self.assertIsInstance(res, six.string_types) self._check_usage(objects.NUMATopology.obj_from_db_obj(res)) def test_instance_with_fetch(self): host = objects.ComputeNode(numa_topology=self.hosttopo._to_json()) fake_uuid = str(uuid.uuid4()) instance = {'uuid': fake_uuid} with mock.patch.object(objects.InstanceNUMATopology, 'get_by_instance_uuid', return_value=None) as get_mock: res = compat.get_host_numa_usage_from_instance(host, instance) self.assertIsInstance(res, six.string_types) self.assertTrue(get_mock.called) def test_object_instance_with_load(self): host = objects.ComputeNode(numa_topology=self.hosttopo._to_json()) fake_uuid = str(uuid.uuid4()) instance = objects.Instance(context=self.context, uuid=fake_uuid) with mock.patch.object(objects.InstanceNUMATopology, 'get_by_instance_uuid', return_value=None) as get_mock: res = compat.get_host_numa_usage_from_instance(host, instance) self.assertIsInstance(res, six.string_types) self.assertTrue(get_mock.called) def test_instance_serialized_by_build_request_spec(self): host = objects.ComputeNode(numa_topology=self.hosttopo._to_json()) fake_uuid = str(uuid.uuid4()) instance = objects.Instance(context=self.context, id=1, uuid=fake_uuid, numa_topology=self.instancetopo) # NOTE (ndipanov): This emulates scheduler.utils.build_request_spec # We can remove this test once we no longer use that method. instance_raw = jsonutils.to_primitive( base_obj.obj_to_primitive(instance)) res = compat.get_host_numa_usage_from_instance(host, instance_raw) self.assertIsInstance(res, six.string_types) self._check_usage(objects.NUMATopology.obj_from_db_obj(res)) def test_attr_host(self): class Host(object): def __init__(obj): obj.numa_topology = self.hosttopo._to_json() host = Host() instance = {'numa_topology': self.instancetopo._to_json()} res = compat.get_host_numa_usage_from_instance(host, instance) self.assertIsInstance(res, six.string_types) self._check_usage(objects.NUMATopology.obj_from_db_obj(res)) def test_never_serialize_result(self): host = {'numa_topology': self.hosttopo._to_json()} instance = {'numa_topology': self.instancetopo} res = compat.get_host_numa_usage_from_instance( host, instance, never_serialize_result=True) self.assertIsInstance(res, objects.NUMATopology) self._check_usage(res) def test_dict_numa_topology_to_obj(self): fake_uuid = str(uuid.uuid4()) instance = objects.Instance(context=self.context, id=1, uuid=fake_uuid, numa_topology=self.instancetopo) instance_dict = base_obj.obj_to_primitive(instance) instance_numa_topo = compat.instance_topology_from_instance( instance_dict) for expected_cell, actual_cell in zip(self.instancetopo.cells, instance_numa_topo.cells): for k in expected_cell.fields: self.assertEqual(getattr(expected_cell, k), getattr(actual_cell, k))

commit_message:
tests: Split 'test_hardware' into modules

'hardware.py' was split up. Now do the same for 'test_hardware.py'.

Change-Id: I011086408d9d0804317ae4d2ff57369acd282356

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import collections import mock from nova import exception from nova import objects from nova.objects import fields from nova.pci import stats from nova import test from nova.virt.hardware import numa as hw_numa class NUMATopologyTest(test.NoDBTestCase): def test_topology_constraints(self): testdata = [ { "flavor": objects.Flavor(vcpus=8, memory_mb=2048, extra_specs={ }), "image": { }, "expect": None, }, { "flavor": objects.Flavor(vcpus=8, memory_mb=2048, extra_specs={ "hw:numa_nodes": 2 }), "image": { }, "expect": objects.InstanceNUMATopology(cells= [ objects.InstanceNUMACell( id=0, cpuset=set([0, 1, 2, 3]), memory=1024), objects.InstanceNUMACell( id=1, cpuset=set([4, 5, 6, 7]), memory=1024), ]), }, { "flavor": objects.Flavor(vcpus=8, memory_mb=2048, extra_specs={ "hw:mem_page_size": 2048 }), "image": { }, "expect": objects.InstanceNUMATopology(cells=[ objects.InstanceNUMACell( id=0, cpuset=set([0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]), memory=2048, pagesize=2048) ]), }, { # vcpus is not a multiple of nodes, so it # is an error to not provide cpu/mem mapping "flavor": objects.Flavor(vcpus=8, memory_mb=2048, extra_specs={ "hw:numa_nodes": 3 }), "image": { }, "expect": exception.ImageNUMATopologyAsymmetric, }, { "flavor": objects.Flavor(vcpus=8, memory_mb=2048, extra_specs={ "hw:numa_nodes": 3, "hw:numa_cpus.0": "0-3", "hw:numa_mem.0": "1024", "hw:numa_cpus.1": "4,6", "hw:numa_mem.1": "512", "hw:numa_cpus.2": "5,7", "hw:numa_mem.2": "512", }), "image": { }, "expect": objects.InstanceNUMATopology(cells= [ objects.InstanceNUMACell( id=0, cpuset=set([0, 1, 2, 3]), memory=1024), objects.InstanceNUMACell( id=1, cpuset=set([4, 6]), memory=512), objects.InstanceNUMACell( id=2, cpuset=set([5, 7]), memory=512) ]), }, { "flavor": objects.Flavor(vcpus=8, memory_mb=2048, extra_specs={ }), "image": { "properties": { "hw_numa_nodes": 3, "hw_numa_cpus.0": "0-3", "hw_numa_mem.0": "1024", "hw_numa_cpus.1": "4,6", "hw_numa_mem.1": "512", "hw_numa_cpus.2": "5,7", "hw_numa_mem.2": "512", }, }, "expect": objects.InstanceNUMATopology(cells= [ objects.InstanceNUMACell( id=0, cpuset=set([0, 1, 2, 3]), memory=1024), objects.InstanceNUMACell( id=1, cpuset=set([4, 6]), memory=512), objects.InstanceNUMACell( id=2, cpuset=set([5, 7]), memory=512) ]), }, { # Request a CPU that is out of range # wrt vCPU count "flavor": objects.Flavor(vcpus=8, memory_mb=2048, extra_specs={ "hw:numa_nodes": 1, "hw:numa_cpus.0": "0-16", "hw:numa_mem.0": "2048", }), "image": { }, "expect": exception.ImageNUMATopologyCPUOutOfRange, }, { # Request the same CPU in two nodes "flavor": objects.Flavor(vcpus=8, memory_mb=2048, extra_specs={ "hw:numa_nodes": 2, "hw:numa_cpus.0": "0-7", "hw:numa_mem.0": "1024", "hw:numa_cpus.1": "0-7", "hw:numa_mem.1": "1024", }), "image": { }, "expect": spec=[{'vendor_id': '8086'}]) pci_reqs = [pci_request] pci_stats = stats.PciDeviceStats() with mock.patch.object(stats.PciDeviceStats, 'support_requests', return_value= False): fitted_instance1 = hw_numa.numa_fit_instance_to_host( self.host, self.instance1, pci_requests=pci_reqs, pci_stats=pci_stats) self.assertIsNone(fitted_instance1) class _CPUPinningTestCaseBase(object): def assertEqualTopology(self, expected, got): for attr in ('sockets', 'cores', 'threads'): self.assertEqual(getattr(expected, attr), getattr(got, attr), "Mismatch on %s" % attr) def assertInstanceCellPinned(self, instance_cell, cell_ids=None): default_cell_id = 0 self.assertIsNotNone(instance_cell) if cell_ids is None: self.assertEqual(default_cell_id, instance_cell.id) else: self.assertIn(instance_cell.id, cell_ids) self.assertEqual(len(instance_cell.cpuset), len(instance_cell.cpu_pinning)) def assertPinningPreferThreads(self, instance_cell, host_cell): """Make sure we are preferring threads. We do this by assessing that at least 2 CPUs went to the same core if that was even possible to begin with. """ max_free_siblings = max(map(len, host_cell.free_siblings)) if len(instance_cell) > 1 and max_free_siblings > 1: cpu_to_sib = {} for sib in host_cell.free_siblings: for cpu in sib: cpu_to_sib[cpu] = tuple(sorted(sib)) pins_per_sib = collections.defaultdict(int) for inst_p, host_p in instance_cell.cpu_pinning.items(): pins_per_sib[cpu_to_sib[host_p]] += 1 self.assertGreater(max(pins_per_sib.values()), 1, "Seems threads were not preferred by the " "pinning logic.") class CPUPinningCellTestCase(test.NoDBTestCase, _CPUPinningTestCaseBase): def commit_message:
Using assertIsNone() instead of assertIs(None, ..)

Following OpenStack Style Guidelines[1]:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#unit-tests-and-assertraises
[H203] Unit test assertions tend to give better messages for more
specific assertions. As a result, assertIsNone(...) is preferred
over assertEqual(None, ...) and assertIs(..,None)

Change-Id: I051dff5e7b940ea36800952f7a82c7e9c2348866
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/20/374720/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Security issue refactor for wrap_exception notification

Adding a filter for safe exceptions and using strutils.password_mask()
for the exception_message.

Partially-Implements: bp versioned-notification-transformation-ocata
Change-Id: I4bc891ad7d066aa500d90a1da80f8318ecdf36cd

commit_message:
[WIP] Allow mapping multiple Neutron ports to Ironic ports

This patch allows multiple Neutron port ids to be mapped to a single
Ironic port or portgroup by changing the vif_port_id field into a list
called vif_port_ids, and updates the network providers and dhcp plugins
to understand the new format. This is the Nova part of enabling
VLAN aware Baremetal instances.

Change-Id: I7111821f48de635821b3a5ae898a7c1c0650c6dd
Related-Bug: #1543584
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/12/289412/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.network.neutronv2 import api as neutronfrom nova.virt import netutils def _objs_to_dicts(self, objs): dicts = [] for obj in objs: dicts.append(obj.to_dict()) return dicts def _get_port_for_vif(self, ports, vif): for port in ports: if vif in port.extra['vif_port_ids']: return port def _get_network_metadata(self, node, network_info): client = neutron.get_client(None, admin=True) # Get vlan to port map net_vlan_map = {} port_vlan_map = {} for vif in network_info: if vif['network']['id'] not in net_vlan_map: network = client.show_network(vif['network']['id']) net_vlan_map[vif['network']['id']] = ( network['network']['provider:segmentation_id']) port_vlan_map[vif['id']] = net_vlan_map[vif['network']['id']] network_metadata = netutils.get_network_metadata(network_info) ports = self.ironicclient.call("node.list_ports", node.uuid, detail=True) portgroups = self.ironicclient.call("node.list_portgroups", node.uuid) all_ports = ports + portgroups for link in network_metadata['links']: link['type'] = 'vlan' link['vlan_mac_address'] = link['ethernet_mac_address'] link['neutron_port_id'] = link['vif_id'] link['vlan_id'] = commit_message:
Extract duplicated code from compute manager

(nova/compute/manager.py)
In the _do_build_and_run_instance method the exceptions are treated in
the very similar way, when a _build_and_run_instance call fails. So
I extracted these clean up calls into a new method. I did it based on
the following link (159~CloneClass):
http://openqa.sed.hu/sourcemeter_duplications/load_duplications_page?data_key=OpenStack:nova:nova/compute/manager.py
I also added unit test to the new method

Change-Id: I41f12800082243118747417f01dab8063fc47742

commit_message:
driver-teams: add resolution requiring teams to accept driver contributions

The OpenStack community wants to encourage collaboration between
vendors. The best way to do this, while maintaining a level playing
field for all contributors, is to require teams that provide driver
interfaces to accept contributions of drivers written to those
interfaces.

Change-Id: I56c075b6f758c12c660a7ea2f1933e8194db0782
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/30/403830/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================================================== 2016-11-21 Require Project Teams to Host Vendor-specific Drivers ================================================================== The OpenStack community wants to encourage collaboration by emphasizing contributions to projects that abstract differences between vendor-specific products, while still empowering vendors to integrate their products with OpenStack through drivers that can be consumed by the abstraction layers. We strongly prefer that drivers are included in the consuming projects and managed by the same contributors in a collaborative fashion, whether by including drivers "in tree" or by placing them in separate repositories owned by the same team. Some teams for projects that use drivers may not want to manage some or all of the drivers that can be consumed by their project, for a variety of reasons. Our :doc:`../reference/new-projects-requirements` list includes a statement about establishing a "level and open collaboration playing field" The project shall provide a level and open collaboration playing field for all contributors. The project shall not benefit a single vendor, or a single vendors product offerings; nor advantage contributors from a single vendor organization due to access to source code, hardware, resources or other proprietary technology available only to those contributors. Refusing a contributed vendor-specific driver places us in the untenable position of rejecting contributions from organizations that otherwise support the community, making our collaboration space unbalanced. This is not acceptable. Therefore, all project teams with driver interfaces must accept vendor-specific driver contributions, either in-tree or in a separate vendor repository owned by the project team. The project core review team does not need to accept responsibility for the code quality of those drivers, if they are not in-tree. Neither do they need to participate in code reviews, so long as the maintainers of the code are given sufficient access rights to allow them to work on the driver following our established community review guidelines. The project core team does not need to claim that the drivers are supported unless the driver meets reasonable criteria, to be set by the project team, such as reliable third-party CI testing, sufficient unit test coverage, etc. These criteria need to be objective and documented in the contributor documentation for the consuming projects. Drivers that languish unmaintained may be removed using the standard deprecation processes.

commit_message:
driver-teams: Stop requiring a level playing field

Acknowledge our expectation for a level playing field but resolve
that it is not necessary to require one, and that attempting to do
so inhibits tighter integration of driver development for
proprietary systems with the rest of the community. Remove this
principle as a strict requirement.

Change-Id: Ia31336419e37397d90f52ccaced239f0e3c3d8f4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/38/403838/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================================= 2016-11-28 Stop requiring a level playing field ================================================= The OpenStack community holds a strong belief in open, inclusive collaboration at all stages of software design and development. The "Empowering Businesses, on a Level Playing Field" principle reflects a desired outcome within our community, but the "level playing field" requirement precludes valuable contributions which we wish to encourage through the possibility of official team status. Its removal is not a rejection of this principle, but merely an acknowledgement that the inertia within our community already effectively supports collaboration and inhibits success for less inclusive teams. Rather than attempt to enforce a level playing field, allow it to form naturally through community pressure and values.

commit_message:
driver-teams: Proprietary driver dev is unlevel

Reaffirm that OpenStack is about enabling open collaboration and our
dedication to maintaining a level playing field. Resolve that
development of drivers for proprietary systems, while important, is
incompatible with this principle and so those developers focused
solely on drivers will not be recognized as official teams by the
OpenStack technical committee.

Change-Id: I632f574bbd2321980765489fcd9c72df1422581c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/34/403834/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ======================================================================= 2016-11-28 Proprietary driver development is an unlevel playing field ======================================================================= The OpenStack community holds a strong belief in open, inclusive collaboration at all stages of software design and development. Drivers for proprietary systems are inherently developed by an inner circle of those with access to proprietary information about the systems they support, lacking substantive collaboration with outside contributors. While we appreciate the work done within our broader ecosystem to support popular hardware and similar proprietary components, OpenStack does not consider them "official" community activity and so does not recognize those responsible as eligible for resources granted to teams within the "Big Tent."

commit_message:
Resolve systemd trusty issue

Ansible fails to detect upstart properly on trusty systems where
systemd is running, due to the existence of /run/systemd/system.

As shown in the testing here: http://cdn.pasteraw.com/l0ua0oxpnyu4qjwuztg59grbyqp3tqx
installing the systemd-shim package disables systemd and removes
/run/systemd/system, preventing this issue.

Change-Id: I6a535181c85a0f89cfbfb812051f65eb5ce8e3d4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_hosts refs/changes/12/409312/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - systemd-shim

commit_message:
Consistently use a exception vs sys.exit

This also makes it so that the config check
accumulates errors instead of bailing out
immediatly (using a sys.exit) which seems nicer
than blowing up on the first error.

Change-Id: I915ef5a018969eee87ac1ab3ddc88fc1b89a3448

commit_message:
Add ability to output the things built/failed/not build

Instead of having users of kolla image building grep the
output of kolla (or grep `docker images` before and after
kolla is ran) to find what was actually built have kolla
be able to write exactly what was built (thus avoiding the
whole docker and grep stuff).

Closes-Bug: #1640973

Change-Id: I11c031b4ded2ff780fa3ceb809a2ee232b36100c

subject: Fix can't generate heka-custom.toml on multi-nodes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-02 09:27:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/74e02bfa461c2e4a79a5c63deb0f826fd8aab286', 'message': "Fix can't generate heka-custom.toml on multi-nodes

Original we judge heka-custom.toml whether exist with stat: path=
method, but it doesn't execute on multi-nodes, only executes on one
node with kolla host. So if using kolla to deploy multi-nodes,
user's heka-custom.toml will not be rendered on target nodes.
In order to solve this problem, it is necessary define an empty
heka-custom.toml file under templates directory and use ansible's
with_first_found feature to render user's heka-custom.toml first.

Change-Id: Id4a124499d1db03b16cb8af231a394b53fe44cbf
Closes-Bug: #1646732
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-12-02 09:39:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/37fdc0ea8732566502c568b624385727ea7bde50', 'message': "Fix can't generate heka-custom.toml on multi-nodes

Original we judge heka-custom.toml whether exist with stat: path=
method, but it doesn't execute on multi-nodes, only executes on one
node with kolla host. So if using kolla to deploy multi-nodes,
user's heka-custom.toml will not be rendered on target nodes.
In order to solve this problem, it is necessary to define an empty
heka-custom.toml file under templates directory and use ansible's
with_first_found feature to render user's heka-custom.toml first.

Change-Id: Id4a124499d1db03b16cb8af231a394b53fe44cbf
Closes-Bug: #1646732
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-12-08 09:50:45.000000000', 'files': ['ansible/roles/common/tasks/config.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/4396cae2b897062ae731d26c4ba8ead885ed0791', 'message': "Fix can't generate heka-custom.toml on multi-nodes

Original we judge heka-custom.toml whether exists with stat: path=

Closes-Bug: #1646732
"}]
commit_message:
Fix can't generate heka-custom.toml on multi-nodes

Original we judge heka-custom.toml whether exists with stat: path=
method, but if deploy on multi-nodes, should add local_action.

Change-Id: Id4a124499d1db03b16cb8af231a394b53fe44cbf
Closes-Bug: #1646732

Change-Id: I10e0dafb6138d91facdb66a2f487cdeca4689c28

commit_message:
Read EXTRA_OPTS from env in kolla-ansible script

Read EXTRA_OPTS from env make it possible that using arbitrary
ansible-playbook parameters in kolla-ansible script. like

    EXTRA_OPTS='--limit control' kolla-ansible deploy

Change-Id: I10e0dafb6138d91facdb66a2f487cdeca4689c28
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/71/406671/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: EXTRA_OPTS=${EXTRA_OPTS}

commit_message:
Swift data transfer should not be using the API Network

The account, container, and object templates were incorrectly
using the api_interface as their bind_ip configuration setting.

Updated these templates to instead use the storage_interface.

Change-Id: I683102096cd6aa3c77a7900f5a1a248cdcddba42
Note: Rings must be generated accordingly.
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/65/407665/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: bind_ip = {{ hostvars[inventory_hostname]['ansible_' + storage_interface]['ipv4']['address'] }}

stevedore_driver from octavia.common import data_models from octavia.common import exceptions from octavia.db import repositories from octavia.i18n import _LE CONF = cfg.CONF LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class BaseController(rest.RestController): def __init__(self): super(BaseController, self).__init__() self.repositories = repositories.Repositories() self.handler = stevedore_driver.DriverManager( namespace='octavia.api.handlers', name=CONF.api_handler, invoke_on_load=True ).driver @staticmethod def _convert_db_to_type(db_entity, to_type, children=False): """Converts a data model into a Octavia WSME type :param db_entity: data model to convert :param to_type: converts db_entity to this time """ if isinstance(to_type, list): to_type = to_type[0] def _convert(db_obj): return to_type.from_data_model(db_obj, children=children) if isinstance(db_entity, list): converted = [_convert(db_obj) for db_obj in db_entity] else: converted = _convert(db_entity) return converted @staticmethod def _get_db_obj(session, repo, data_model, id): """Gets an object from the database and returns it.""" db_obj = repo.get(session, id=id) if not db_obj: LOG.exception(_LE("{name} {id} not found").format( name=data_model._name(), id=id)) raise exceptions.NotFound( resource=data_model._name(), id=id) return db_obj def _get_db_lb(self, session, id): """Get a load balancer from the database.""" return self._get_db_obj(session, self.repositories.load_balancer, data_models.LoadBalancer, id) def _get_db_listener(self, session, id): """Get a listener from the database.""" return self._get_db_obj(session, self.repositories.listener, data_models.Listener, id) def _get_db_pool(self, session, id): """Get a pool from the database.""" return self._get_db_obj(session, self.repositories.pool, data_models.Pool, id) def _get_db_member(self, session, id): """Get a member from the database.""" return self._get_db_obj(session, self.repositories.member, data_models.Member, id) def _get_db_l7policy(self, session, id): """Get a L7 Policy from the database.""" return self._get_db_obj(session, self.repositories.l7policy, data_models.L7Policy, id) def _get_db_l7rule(self, session, id): """Get a L7 Rule from the database.""" return self._get_db_obj(session, self.repositories.l7rule, data_models.L7Rule, id)

commit_message:
Use different file content to test max_number_personality_files

In test_can_create_server_with_max_number_personality_files,
the max number of personality files are created with the same
content, we can use different file contents to make the testcase
more accurate.

Change-Id: Id572d6d0b7e705bfa075074eeed20de338dbd3fc

commit_message:
Remove type field and type description for create volume from a snapshot

The new volume should have the same type as the snapshot that the volume
is created from. Setting a different type will get an error from the API.

This behavior should be the same when creating a volume from the Volumes
tab and the Volume Snapshots tab.

Closes-bug: #1582458

Change-Id: I0443eb5c6cb18538ff76fc49d4018221691a2ea2

subject: Make RPCFixture support multiple connections
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-10 21:57:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7d458ba30141c1a2d4179558bf123c6ce07ffb93', 'message': "Make RPCFixture support multiple connections

For testing cells, we will need to track the driver instances that
we give out by url. This normally just works with a conventional
oslo.messaging driver, but the fake driver keeps internal data
structures for simulating its bus. If we end up with clients creating
a new instance of the driver in the rpc switching code, we'll never
be able to send messages to services because we'll always have
private/separate data structures.

So, this makes the fixture wrap create_transport() so it can keep
and unify references by url.

Change-Id: Icb63d7dabd17f3c5633387793f68a8ba20863a7e

"}, {'number': 18, 'created': '2016-12-05 16:29:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/00de5655f599b1e2f6988b32e24909da4c63bcd9', 'message': "Make RPCFixture support multiple connections

For testing cells, we will need to track the driver instances that
we give out by url. This normally just works with a conventional
oslo.messaging driver, but the fake driver keeps internal data
structures for simulating its bus. If we end up with clients creating
a new instance of the driver in the rpc switching code, we'll never
be able to send messages to services because we'll always have
private/separate data structures.

So, this makes the fixture wrap the transport creation stuff
and unify references by url. In order to make this work, some
retooling of rpc.init() is done, which makes it more in line with
the recent additions we had for wrapping transport initialization
per connection anyway.

For now, a lot of our tests can't handle the possibility of
multiple RPC connections due to them looking at the global
transport_url configuration. So for the moment, even though this
makes the fixture support multiple independent connections, we
collapse any such attempts down to a single connection to the
default broker.

Change-Id: Icb63d7dabd17f3c5633387793f68a8ba20863a7e

collapse any such attempts down to a single connection to the
default broker.

Note: this requires a fix in oslo.messaging 5.14.0

Depends-On: I01b6f5a20ea9752da46a546a908bd38cf11da681
Change-Id: Icb63d7dabd17f3c5633387793f68a8ba20863a7e
"}]
commit_message:
Make RPCFixture support multiple connections

For testing cells, we will need to track the driver instances that
we give out by url. This normally just works with a conventional
oslo.messaging driver, but the fake driver keeps internal data
structures for simulating its bus. If we end up with clients creating
a new instance of the driver in the rpc switching code, we'll never
be able to send messages to services because we'll always have
private/separate data structures.

So, this makes the fixture wrap the transport creation stuff
and unify references by url. In order to make this work, some
retooling of rpc.init() is done, which makes it more in line with
the recent additions we had for wrapping transport initialization
per connection anyway.

For now, a lot of our tests can't handle the possibility of
multiple RPC connections due to them looking at the global
transport_url configuration. So for the moment, even though this
makes the fixture support multiple independent connections, we
collapse any such attempts down to a single connection to the
default broker.

Note: this requires a fix in oslo.messaging 5.14.0

Depends-On: I01b6f5a20ea9752da46a546a908bd38cf11da681
Change-Id: Icb63d7dabd17f3c5633387793f68a8ba20863a7e

New class for Software Deployment resources

Create new class for better reusability and clarity as discussed in the
patch review, https://review.openstack.org/#/c/407104/

Change-Id: Iba123c963a0d3851a0ac62bb865b22c6fd0165d3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-translator refs/changes/05/408805/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sw_deployment_resouce = HOTSoftwareDeploymentResources(hosting_server) server_key = sw_deployment_resouce.server_key servers = sw_deployment_resouce.servers sw_deploy_res = sw_deployment_resouce.software_deployment sw_deployment_resouce = \ HOTSoftwareDeploymentResources(hosting_on_server) server_key = sw_deployment_resouce.server_key sw_deploy_res = sw_deployment_resouce.software_deployment sw_deployment_resouce = HOTSoftwareDeploymentResources(hosting_server) server_key = sw_deployment_resouce.server_key servers = sw_deployment_resouce.servers sw_deploy_res = sw_deployment_resouce.software_deployment sw_deploy_group = \ HOTSoftwareDeploymentResources().software_deployment_group sw_deploy = HOTSoftwareDeploymentResources().software_deployment class HOTSoftwareDeploymentResources(object): """Provides HOT Software Deployment resources SoftwareDeployment or SoftwareDeploymentGroup Resource """ def __init__(self, hosting_server=None): self.software_deployment = 'OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment' self.software_deployment_group = 'OS::Heat::SoftwareDeploymentGroup' self.server_key = 'server' self.hosting_server = hosting_server self.servers = {} if hosting_server is not None: if len(self.hosting_server) == 1: if isinstance(hosting_server, list): self.servers['get_resource'] = self.hosting_server[0] else: for server in self.hosting_server: self.servers[server] = {'get_resource': server} self.software_deployment = self.software_deployment_group self.server_key = 'servers'
deleted_lines: servers = {} server_key = 'server' sw_deploy_res = 'OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment' if hosting_server is not None: if len(hosting_server) == 1: servers['get_resource'] = hosting_server[0] else: for server in hosting_server: servers[server] = {'get_resource': server} sw_deploy_res += 'Group' server_key = 'servers' server_key = 'server' sw_deploy_res = 'OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment' if len(hosting_on_server.keys()) > 1: server_key += 's' sw_deploy_res += 'Group' servers = {} server_key = 'server' sw_deploy_res = 'OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment' if hosting_server is not None: if len(hosting_server) == 1: servers['get_resource'] = hosting_server[0] else: for server in hosting_server: servers[server] = {'get_resource': server} sw_deploy_res += 'Group' server_key = 'servers' sw_deploy_group = 'OS::Heat::SoftwareDeploymentGroup' sw_deploy = 'OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment'

commit_message:
remove cookbook dependency version pinning

* cookbook version pinning should only happen in the cookbooks
themselves to avoid conflicts during integration-tests

commit_message:
Use assertGreater(len(x), 0) instead of assertTrue(len(x) > 0)

assertGreater provides a nicer error message if it fails.

Change-Id: Ic6d554c6a5e648d12a313257d6c8beec1b60ce3d

- Remove Precise Amulet test definitions if present.

commit_message:
Fix pci_alias that include white spaces

When the PCI alias was getting translated to a PCI request,
all the white spaces were getting removed. So the pci_passthrough:alias
specified in the flavor never matched the device in pci_alias.
This patch fixes the bug by only stripping the white spaces
at the beginning or the end of the elements

Conflicts:
  nova/tests/unit/pci/test_request.py

NOTE(lyarwood): Test conflict caused by the reorganisation of PCI options
as part of I886045ab4e6bdb8418fd1ccdcd811417ecb4ad4a.

Change-Id: I2888b03faf6c25bcb6011db40100d925972c2231
Closes-Bug: #1638200
(cherry picked from commit 9b88e755d93200811487d2f778735869f8fe07af)

subject: Handle MarkerNotFound from cell0 database
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-07 01:38:29.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_api.py', 'nova/compute/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0be839bdfbf15e551b4e6a2788b20502db1933c4', 'message': "Handle MarkerNotFound from cell0 database

When listing instances in the cellv2 world we look them up
from three locations:

1. Build requests which exist before the instances are created
   in the cell database (after the scheduler picks a host to
   build the instance). Currently instances and build requests
   are both created before casting to conductor, but that's going
   away in Ocata with the support for multiple cellsv2 cells.
2. The cell0 database for instances which failed to get scheduled
   to a compute host (and therefore a cell).
3. The actual cell database that the instance lives in. Currently
   that's only a single traditional nova database, but could be one
   of multiple cellsv2 cells when we add that support in Ocata.

If a marker is passed in when listing instances, if the instance
lives in an actual cell database, we'll get a MarkerNotFound failure
from cell0 because the instance doesn't exist in cell0, but we check
cell0 before we check the cell database. This makes the instance
listing short-circuit and fail with a 400 from the REST API.

This patch simply handles the MarkerNotFound when listing instances
from the cell0 database and ignores it so we can continue onto the
cell database.

Closes-Bug: #1647464

Change-Id: I977497be262fb7f2333e32fb7313b29624323422
(cherry picked from commit 72d28ccd6e8ce8cf700891788f06578313b03c38)
"}]
commit_message:
Handle MarkerNotFound from cell0 database

When listing instances in the cellv2 world we look them up
from three locations:

1. Build requests which exist before the instances are created
   in the cell database (after the scheduler picks a host to
   build the instance). Currently instances and build requests
   are both created before casting to conductor, but that's going
   away in Ocata with the support for multiple cellsv2 cells.
2. The cell0 database for instances which failed to get scheduled
   to a compute host (and therefore a cell).
3. The actual cell database that the instance lives in. Currently
   that's only a single traditional nova database, but could be one
   of multiple cellsv2 cells when we add that support in Ocata.

If a marker is passed in when listing instances, if the instance
lives in an actual cell database, we'll get a MarkerNotFound failure
from cell0 because the instance doesn't exist in cell0, but we check
cell0 before we check the cell database. This makes the instance
listing short-circuit and fail with a 400 from the REST API.

This patch simply handles the MarkerNotFound when listing instances
from the cell0 database and ignores it so we can continue onto the
cell database.

Closes-Bug: #1647464

Change-Id: I977497be262fb7f2333e32fb7313b29624323422
(cherry picked from commit 72d28ccd6e8ce8cf700891788f06578313b03c38)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/91/407791/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Using get() method to prevent KeyError

Using get() to access keys like "summary.guest.toolsStatus" and
"summary.guest.toolrunningStatus" to avoid exception during hard reboot.
This change would use a default values even if they don't exist in dict
as we can have VMs where VM tools wouldn't be installed/running which leads
to hard reboot

Change-Id: I332867fe783d6d47b81d8a53153af140d4158217
Closes-bug: #1563325
(cherry picked from commit d3c7396d87681b82327c59c27fe14cf5e20c3ba5)

commit_message:
Show team and repo badges on README

This patch adds the team's and repository's badges to the README file.
The motivation behind this is to communicate the project status and
features at first glance.

For more information about this effort, please read this email thread:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-October/105562.html

To see an example of how this would look like check:

b'https://gist.github.com/9a0f7bcf2ea57d7c87651330c4a18ec1\n'

Change-Id: I0190e086f8eb1b19c07beb27387f87ba8e9e20db

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-09 05:24:11.000000000', 'files': ['manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/test_security_services.py', 'manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/test_share_networks.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/00221d59b9ae8bcfd80fea8d757a4a1e95c84cae', 'message': 'Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using
six.iteritems to achieve iterators. We can
use dict.items instead, as it will return
iterators in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys
will more readable. 2.In py2, the performance
about list should be negligible, see the link [2].
[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3

Change-Id: Ic68ba358d51002e1a1aeac6159248ffb730b5daf

commit_message:
Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using
six.iteritems to achieve iterators. We can
use dict.items instead, as it will return
iterators in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys
will more readable. 2.In py2, the performance
about list should be negligible, see the link [2].
[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: Ic68ba358d51002e1a1aeac6159248ffb730b5daf

commit_message:
Update "Add community-level image sharing' spec

This patch updates the spec so that it accurately reflects the
implementation.  In particular, it adds justification for making
'shared' the default image visibility and provides more discussion
of end user impact.

Change-Id: I93d0c15f8991f8d4a802c2c0c7a0a00a24b2ac50
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/19/396919/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: affect an image's internal member-list. To be precise, consistent with current behavior: * An image's member-list persists even when the visibility of an image has changed to a value that renders the member-list inert. * Image member operations (that is, creating image members or changing the member_status of image members) are allowed only when an image has a visibility under which the member-list is *not* inert. The justification for this is that it is confusing to users to be able to perform member operations on an image when these operations have no effect on the accessiblity of the image.The default value for ``visibility`` is ``shared``. (See :ref:`other-impact` for a discussion.)2. For all other rows: (See :ref:`other-impact` for why this is the appropriate setting.).. _other-impact:Consistent with current functionality, when a visibility is specified at the time of image creation, that visibility will be respected. If the user creating the image does not have appropriate permissions to set the specified visibility value on an image, the image-create call will fail as it does now. In order to preserve backward compatability with the current workflow for sharing an image, the default ``visibility`` of an image will be ``shared``: * An image with shared visibility and no image members is not accessible to anyone other than the image owner, so this respects the current behavior. * Currently, when an image is created with default visibility, the owner can immediately add members to the image to share it. By making the default visibility value ``shared``, we preserve this behavior. If the default visibility were ``private``, then this behavior would be broken as the image owner would have to make an API call to change the visibility of the image to ``shared`` before members could be added. * Although the Image API v1 is deprecated in Newton, it still exists and will likely be deployed in clouds using the Ocata release of OpenStack. Since the v1 API has no concept of visibility, there's no way for a user to change the visibility to ``shared`` so that an image can have members added to it. By making the default visibility ``shared``, we achieve the following desirable results: * A v1 user can create an image and add members using the current workflow, that is, sharing an image is simply a matter of putting a member on it. * In deployments using both v1 and v2 of the Image API, if an image is created using v1 and then an image-show call is made in v2, the visibility of ``shared`` makes it clear to the v2 user that the image is in a state where it can both accept members and be accessed by any existing members. If the default visibility value were *not* ``shared``, then v1 would need to be modified so that ``private`` images could accept members and be accessed by members. This, however, would create a situation where an image would behave radically differently depending upon whether you tried to access it by the v1 or the v2 API. We don't want to do that. A key question here is whether changing the default visibility from ``private`` to ``shared`` introduces a backward incompatibility into the v2 API. Here are three arguments that it does not: 1. The current situation is that the ``visibility`` of an image created by a non-admin user has ``visibility`` != ``public``. That situation is preserved. 2. If we *don't* make the default visibility ``shared``, then we are in fact introducing a backward incompatibility in that any current user scripts that create an image and then immediately add members to it will break. (This was in fact a problem with an earlier version of this spec. While the API working group agreed that it was a "minor" backward incompatibility that would be permissible, they pointed out that Glance users were likely to be annoyed by the workflow change. The change in ``visibility`` value is a lesser of two evils.) 3. What we want to be the case is that when a user creates an image without specifying a visibility, the image behaves the same way it does now. Images that behave in that way have the visibility that we now call ``shared``. This is to be expected; previously, we had insufficient keywords to identify the various accessibility statuses of images; now we do, and we should use these keywords appropriately. The conclusion is that setting the default visibility to ``private`` would have a greater end user impact than the proposal to make the default visibility value ``shared``. Note that if the v2 API is used to set the visibility of an image to ``private``, if the v1 API is used to share the image, the request will fail with a 409 (as it will if a member-related call is made to the v2 API). This is appropriate, as someone has explicitly disabled sharing for that image.
deleted_lines: affect an image's internal member-list. The default value for ``visibility`` is ``'private'``.2. For all unique ``image_id`` in ``image_members`` where ``deleted != 1``:3. For all other rows: - ``visibility = 'private'``In order to maintain consistency with how visibility is set, the current v2 image-sharing workflow will be impacted. Currently sharing an image is simply a matter of putting a member on it. Since this change adds an explicit ``shared`` value for visiblity, the new workflow for image-sharing would then first require the owner or an admin to set it to ``shared`` with an image-update call: :: PATCH /v2/images/{image_id} Request body: :: [{ "op": "replace", "path": "/visibility", "value": "shared" }] This impact has been discussed with the API Workgroup, and they are okay with it. (For reference, please see 16:26:47 on eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/api_wg/2016/api_wg.2016-06-09-15.59.log.html)

commit_message:
Use project_domain_id only in password auth

The method being changed constructs domain-related parameters that will
further be passed to the auth plugin. If project domain is not
passed, the method sets it to the default domain.

token_endpoint does not expect any information about domain,
because it uses only a token and URL. Passing it to auth plugin causes
an exception.

Construct domain-related parameters only for specific plugins, such
as password or totp.

Change-Id: I13db3bbe31a0ed843e9f4528d37c768546e2bee9
Closes-Bug: 1642301
(cherry picked from commit e51a8d63747932f2ee4ffab02dfb0cd43e4a103d)

commit_message:
Use stable/newton branch in tox_install.sh and tox.ini

This change modifies tox_install.sh wrapper to pick dependencies
for the correct branch for stable/newton release.

Adjust upper-constraints.txt in tox.ini to pick dependencies
from stable/newton branch.

commit_message:
Mask passwords in debug logs for auth_config_hook

The auth config hook can have credentials in it so
we have to mask the config before logging it. To
avoid doing the work of masking the password if we
aren't going to log it, there is a conditional put
around the actual debug statement.

Conflicts:
        openstackclient/common/client_config.py

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict was due to imports.

Change-Id: I8e626672ec94fc837610216bccb4354dbdedca17
Closes-Bug: #1630822
(cherry picked from commit cd1a412408f068aeef97c1ee368400307fce7733)

commit_message:
Set noop dhcp provider for ironicclient func tests

This environment doesn't have devstack, don't use neutron as a DHCP
provider. We don't actually DHCP in this environment, but the noop
network interface isn't compatible with it.

Change-Id: I0dbacf36cb1f9bc513481fae3a7282037769ef01
Depends-On: If601934d0c59b5dd5556336e5644832dc7564548
Closes-Bug: #1648179

commit_message:
[AMQP 1.0] Simplify the I/O event loop code

Leverage the fact that there is never more than one socket active to
simplify the event loop's I/O processing.  This removes the need to
look up active connections.  Also removes the need to query the return
values from select since there is only one socket to process. This
change improves RPC throughput under the simulator by up to 20%

As part of this change I've clarified the code's use of the pyngus
connection by renaming the connection property to something a bit more
specific.

Change-Id: If7c020bb0bd96490af78bc06659db10073b02417

commit_message:
Fix a unit test that was attempting real requests

One of the rest driver unit tests was not mocking out the requests
module causing it to attempt to make https get requests.
This patch corrects that oversight.

Change-Id: Iff99207883483ff7f886f62c03664446eb0df492
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/58/408358/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import requests @mock.patch('requests.Session.get', side_effect=requests.ConnectionError) def test_request(self, mock_sleep, mock_get):

commit_message:
Include mistral::db::sync by default

This is done in most other modules and it doesn't make much sense to
setup mistral without it.

Change-Id: I2f8b6ad7ae3e4defefe58ac749b2268d067167b1

commit_message:
Add the enable_new_services option to nova::compute

Make sure we can set the enable_new_services config
option on the nova compute nodes since it's used to
determine if it should register itself in the database
the first time the service is started.

Change-Id: Ic4b53fd82c228395bf6a1f3d4de63fd219ad30cc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/42/409142/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: context 'with enable_new_services parameter set to false' do let :params do { :enable_new_services => false } it { is_expected.to contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/enable_new_services').with_value(false) } end context 'with enable_new_services parameter set to true' do let :params do { :enable_new_services => true } it { is_expected.to contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/enable_new_services').with_ensure('absent') } end

commit_message:
Conform dpdk settings to ovs 2.6

Options from the DPDK_OPTS env variable
(command line) are shifted into ovsdb.

Change-Id: I3cc004111998b2ae23f04145a1803e5143b0d3b4
Closes-Bug: #1644802
(cherry picked from commit 2bcebb8b8b6b32d9639a938fb0939532472787c9)

commit_message:
Update common deployment for python apis

Rename _common_deployment.yaml to _common_api_python_deployment.yaml,
to make the scope of this template clearer. Also makes haproxy optional.

Partially-Implements: blueprint helm-microservices
Change-Id: Iec52782a5226aa5a9d1d904edc2bf9f24e4af4d7

commit_message:
networking-midonet: Add "full" variants for ml2 and v2 jobs

At this point, they are identical with the non-full variants,
except that the new ones are master only and non-voting.

The plan is to make the existing voting jobs minimum later.
(eg. No advanced services)

Partial-Bug: #1615668
Change-Id: I7951c0f9a5c82dae42ba774f210d21e52dac01c7

Update default environment list

The Blazar code base is not yet compatible with Python 3. Having tox
environments for them is a first step towards fixing it.

Change-Id: I2bc764bd57f09ecaa4575628735ff68791b867cd

commit_message:
Remove pxe_ssh, agent_ssh drivers in docs and devstack

This patch removes pxe_ssh, agent_ssh in dev-quickstart and
ironic-multitenant-networking documents because drivers will be
removed in Ocata cycle or later [1].

[1]http://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/ironic/newton.html#deprecation-notes

Change-Id: I2537f44f6b9ca09f756e1f624cc3ce6266f4dbd8

change of cluster properties. This patch fixes this issue.

commit_message:
Added retries for db_sync

If db sync fails, it is never retried leading to errors. So, this
patch adds retries for db_sync to avoid sync fails.

Change-Id: Ib7162c07542d9c8c81ed35f931a2b91281610774
Related-Bug: #1628580
Closes-Bug: #1645474
(cherry picked from commit 3f8e5d1c542dda2bc261c74fa1dad1d3289aa686)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-sahara refs/changes/93/407093/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try_sleep => 5, tries => 10,

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-06 14:13:52.000000000', 'files': ['README.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove-dashboard/commit/230a112ee6f5d11f31d4cf89cc7ffa9e3fd0594a', 'message': 'Add requirement for cross-process cache

Some of the trove-dashboard panels require a cross-process cache
to be used to temporarily store data until it is committed to the
server.  For example, building up the list of configuration

This requirement is now added to the readme to inform users to

Change-Id: I1928da600c7364d8681a8c0b45fe1c66c97032df

'}]
commit_message:
Add requirement for cross-process cache

Some of the trove-dashboard panels require a cross-process cache
to be used to temporarily store data until it is committed to the
server.  For example, building up the list of configuration
parameters is store in the cache until it is applied to the the
database instance.

This requirement is now added to the readme to inform users to
enable the cache.

Change-Id: I1928da600c7364d8681a8c0b45fe1c66c97032df
Closes-Bug: #1638713
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-dashboard refs/changes/27/407527/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Settings ~~~~~~~~ The use of a cross-process cache such as Memcached is required. Install Memcached itself and a Memcached binding such as python-memcached. For a single horizon instance use the CACHES setting like the example below. CACHES = { 'default': { 'BACKEND': 'django.core.cache.backends.memcached.MemcachedCache', 'LOCATION': '127.0.0.1:11211', }, } For multiple horizon instances behind a load balancer configure each instance to use the same cache like the example below. CACHES = { 'default': { 'BACKEND': 'django.core.cache.backends.memcached.MemcachedCache', 'LOCATION': [u'10.2.100.133:11211', u'10.2.100.134:11211''] }, }

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-08 21:34:49.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/inventory/group_vars/neutron_calico_dhcp_agent.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/61f5526945cd2f36b6e5c8a1f9eeba664a1a58d4', 'message': 'Fix default IPv6 BGP peer for BIRD

The jinja calculation of the BIRD BGP peer was failing intermittently
when IPv6 connectivity was not present.

Even though the IPv6 deployment was being detected correctly as
disabled by the role, the configuration task was failing to skip
consistently because the IPv6 peer address var could not be
resolved by Jinja.

This fixes the default IPv6 peer calculation to resolve to an empty
string when no IPv6 connectivity is present, which allows the
automatic IPv6 detection to skip the config task.

Change-Id: If450b237ba349a163f44f40b945c98b14c9d7042
'}]
commit_message:
Fix default IPv6 BGP peer for BIRD

The jinja calculation of the BIRD BGP peer was failing intermittently
when IPv6 connectivity was not present.

Even though the IPv6 deployment was being detected correctly as
disabled by the role, the configuration task was failing to skip
consistently because the IPv6 peer address var could not be
resolved by Jinja.

This fixes the default IPv6 peer calculation to resolve to an empty
string when no IPv6 connectivity is present, which allows the
automatic IPv6 detection to skip the config task.

Change-Id: If450b237ba349a163f44f40b945c98b14c9d7042

subject: TrivialFix: Replace six.iteritems() with .items()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-09 09:03:40.000000000', 'files': ['zun/db/etcd/api.py', 'zun/db/etcd/models.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zun/commit/69460700a2f5902e12c323153417638f9e823efe', 'message': 'TrivialFix: Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using six.iteritems to achieve
iterators. We can use dict.items instead, as it will return iterators
in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys will more readable.
2.In py2, the performance about list should be negligible, see the link [2].

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: I2a201cce19b66d61924738fb89ded7e265b780ec
'}]
commit_message:
TrivialFix: Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using six.iteritems to achieve
iterators. We can use dict.items instead, as it will return iterators
in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys will more readable.
2.In py2, the performance about list should be negligible, see the link [2].

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: I2a201cce19b66d61924738fb89ded7e265b780ec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zun refs/changes/36/409036/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for k, v in values.items():
deleted_lines: import six for k, v in six.iteritems(values):

commit_message:
redis: make sure we don't release and heartbeat a lock at the same time

Otherwise that makes Redis unhappy.

Change-Id: I4659bee93b2112733fe76d329bf73327878c5641
Closes-Bug: #1557593
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tooz refs/changes/55/402055/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(jd) Make sure we don't release and heartbeat at the same time by # using a exclusive access lock (LP#1557593) self._exclusive_access = threading.Lock() with self._exclusive_access: if not self.acquired: with _translate_failures(): try: self._lock.release() except exceptions.LockError: return False self._coord._acquired_locks.discard(self) return True with self._exclusive_access: if self.acquired: with _translate_failures(): self._lock.extend(self._lock.timeout)
deleted_lines: if not self.acquired: return False with _translate_failures(): try: self._lock.release() except exceptions.LockError: self._coord._acquired_locks.discard(self) return True if self.acquired: with _translate_failures(): self._lock.extend(self._lock.timeout)

commit_message:
Added retries in db_sync for nova_api db

That patch continue fixes made for LP#1628580
If db sync fails, it is never retried leading to errors. So, this
patch adds retries for db_sync to avoid sync fails.

Change-Id: Ie718efef81a24d0299fff83d39d04fac5a36fbb0
Related-Bug: #1628580
Related-Bug: #1647305
Closes-Bug: #1645474

commit_message:
Use urlparse.urljoin to join searchlight url

When the searchlight endpoint isn't end with slash, the url generated
will be wrong.

Change-Id: I3e57b9dda9ebe63afd0381d0f9bf2831c4464059
Closes-bug: #1646707
(cherry picked from commit b49a723efe804f96286f03aa22aba7c2299a32a0)

one where you want to take a node down for maintentance,
and two where you really want to stop the whole monasca
stack.  monasca-thresh is a cluster-wide process and can
be stopped from any node in the cluster.  But stopping it
when taking a single node out of service isn't appropriate.

Also update the lag checks for the new/correct way to
get kafka consumer lag.

Change-Id: I333b791c903a45e8a0fc101ade229991a03da2cc

commit_message:
Fix a couple bugs in the stack management script

There are two use cases for a stack restart,
one where you want to take a node down for maintentance,
and two where you really want to stop the whole monasca
stack.  monasca-thresh is a cluster-wide process and can
be stopped from any node in the cluster.  But stopping it
when taking a single node out of service isn't appropriate.

Also update the lag checks for the new/correct way to
get kafka consumer lag.

Change-Id: I333b791c903a45e8a0fc101ade229991a03da2cc

added_lines: INCLUDE_THRESH="include_thresh_flag" echo "zookeeper kafka storm-supervisor storm-nimbus storm-ui" if [ "$1" = "$INCLUDE_THRESH" ] echo "monasca-thresh" if [ "$1" = "$INCLUDE_THRESH" ] echo "monasca-thresh" echo "storm-ui storm-nimbus storm-supervisor kafka zookeeper" for x in $(get_up_list $INCLUDE_THRESH) for x in $(get_up_list $1) for x in $(get_down_list $1) # Print the consumer lag /opt/kafka/bin/kafka-run-class.sh kafka.admin.ConsumerGroupCommand \ --zookeeper localhost:2181 \ --group $1 --describe 2>&1 start-cluster) start $INCLUDE_THRESH ;; stop-cluster) stop $INCLUDE_THRESH ;; restart-cluster) stop $INCLUDE_THRESH sleep 2 start $INCLUDE_THRESH ;; echo "Usage: "$1" {status|start|start-cluster|stop|stop-cluster|restart|restart-cluster|tail-logs|tail-metrics|local-lag|mirror-lag}"
deleted_lines: echo "zookeeper kafka storm-supervisor" if grep nimbus.seeds $STORM_FILE | grep -e $(hostname) -e localhost > /dev/null echo "storm-nimbus storm-ui monasca-thresh" if grep nimbus.host $STORM_FILE | grep -e $(hostname) -e localhost > /dev/null echo "monasca-thresh storm-ui storm-nimbus" echo "storm-supervisor kafka zookeeper" for x in $(get_up_list) for x in $(get_up_list) for x in $(get_down_list) # Print the consumer lag -- ignore java log warnings /opt/kafka/bin/kafka-run-class.sh kafka.tools.ConsumerOffsetChecker \ --zkconnect localhost:2181 \ --topic metrics --group $1 2>&1 \ | grep -v SLF4J echo "Usage: "$1" {status|start|stop|restart|tail-logs|tail-metrics|local-lag|mirror-lag}"
